newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-FORECAST-Boral yr net seen slumping.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-FORECAST-Boral yr net seen slumping.

text.p: Building materials and energy group Boral Ltd is expected to report on Thursday a large fall in net profit before abnormals for the year to June 30 and a possible cut in its final dividend due to a weak housing market.

Building material analysts contacted by Reuters expect Boral to report a net profit before abnormals of between A$165 million and A$185 million for the 1995/96 year, compared with a profit of A$309.7 million a year earlier.
Analysts said the poor result and the demand for capital expenditure could lead to a cut in the final dividend from the 21 cents a share paid in the second half of 1994/95.
Chris Haynes, a building material analyst at BT Securities, expects Boral to report a net profit before abnormals of A$185 million in 1995/96.
"I don't think things are going to be rosy for these guys," said Haynes, who has a underweight recommendation on Boral.

ABN AMRO Hoare Govett building material analyst Fabian Babich forecast Boral to report a net profit before abnormals of A$170 million and the second dividend to remain unchanged at the 21 cents paid a year earlier.
Babich said 1996/97 should also be a tough year for Boral, although a housing recovery in calendar 1997 was expected.
Babich said the result would be very disappointing.

"It's going to be off the planet. When they were talking to Columbus and they said he would never make it, it wasn't a question of missing the mark - it was a question of falling off the map. Well that's what Boral has done," Babich said.
One Melbourne-based analyst forecast Boral to report a net profit before abnormals of A$168 million for 1995/96, but added: "I think it could be worse than that."
"It was a disasterous second half all together," the Melbourne analyst said. He said the fall was due to the sluggish activity in Australia's home building market.
One Sydney-based analyst forecast Boral to report a net profit before abnormals of A$165 million in 1995/96.
Analysts said Boral may cut its second half dividend by up to four cents on the 21 cents a share paid a year earlier.
Boral paid a first half dividend of 10.5 cents, which was steady with the first half dividend of 1994/95.
Boral reported in March a net profit before abnormals of A$120 million in the six months to December 31, 1995.
In March, analysts were forecasting Boral to post a 1995/96 annual net profit of A$240 million to A$250 million.

Analysts said Boral's energy arm should report a firm profit. Overseas earnings should be steady, but should not have much impact on the expected problems in the company's main building material operations in Australia.
Boral shares closed one cent down at A$3.03 on Monday.
The shares have fallen nearly 20 percent from their 1996 year high of A$3.75 hit on March 4.
-- Kevin Morrison, Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373 1800
